Passage:
Regulations to make provision for bank recovery and resolution and connected purposes.
Date of Enactment: 11 December 2018
The Board of Directors of the Abu Dhabi Global Market, in exercise of its powers under Article 6(1) of Law No. 4 of 2013 concerning the Abu Dhabi Global Market issued by His Highness the Ruler of the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, hereby enacts the following Regulations–

NamedEntities.board of directors: group of people comprising the governing body of an organization that has the authority to set organizational strategy and policies as well as to select and, to some degree manage, leadership
NamedEntities.bank: depository institution, usually a corporation, that accepts deposits, makes loans, pays checks, and performs related services, for individual members of the public, businesses or other organizations
NamedEntities.law: rule recognized by some community as regulating the behavior of its members and that it may enforce through the imposition of penalties

DefinedTerms.Board: Means in reference to a corporation, the board of Directors of the corporation.

Passage: General

Definitions
In these Regulations, unless the context otherwise requires—

Additional Tier 1 Capital	means capital instruments that meet the conditions for "AT1 Capital" laid down in the Rules made by the Regulator.
ADGM	means the Abu Dhabi Global Market.
ADGM Branch	means a Branch through which a Non-ADGM Institution carries on Regulated Activities in or from the ADGM.
ADGM Founding Law	means Law No (4) of 2013 concerning the Abu Dhabi Global Market issued by His Highness the Ruler of the Emirate of Abu Dhabi.
ADGM Insolvency Regulations	means the ADGM Insolvency Regulations 2015.
ADGM Parent Institution	means an Institution that has an Institution or Non-ADGM Institution as a subsidiary.
ADGM Parent Undertaking	means a Parent Undertaking—
(a)	registered in and incorporated under the laws of the ADGM; and
(b)	that has an Institution or Non-ADGM Institution as a Subsidiary.
ADGM Subsidiary	means a Subsidiary of an Institution that is registered in and incorporated under the laws of the ADGM.
Affected Creditor 	means a creditor whose claim relates to a liability that is reduced or converted to Shares by the exercise of the Write Down or Conversion Power pursuant to the application of the Bail-in Tool.
Authorised Person	has the meaning given to that term in section 258 of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015.
Bail-in Tool	means the mechanism for recapitalising an Institution or for effecting the exercise of the Write Down or Conversion Power pursuant to section ‎49.

Branch	means a place of business of a legal person which—
(a)	has no separate legal personality; and
(b)	carries out directly all or some of the transactions inherent in the business of Institutions outside the ADGM.
Business of the ADGM Branch	means—
(a)	any rights and liabilities of a Non-ADGM Institution arising as a result of the operations of its ADGM Branch; and
(b)	any other property in the ADGM of the Non-ADGM Institution.
Business Reorganisation Plan	means a Business Reorganisation Plan drawn up and implemented in accordance with section ‎55.

Capital Resources	means the sum of Tier 1 Capital and Tier 2 Capital.
Central Securities Depository	means a legal person that carries out the activity of Acting as a Central Securities Depository, as such term is defined in section 258 of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015.
Client Assets	means Client Money and Client Investments.
Client Money	has the meaning given to that term under section 4 of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015.
Client Investments	means all investments held or controlled on behalf of a client in the course of, or in connection with, the carrying on of investment business.
Collateral Arrangement	has the meaning given to that term under section 298 of the Insolvency Regulations 2015.
Common Equity Tier 1 Capital	means capital instruments that meet the conditions for "CET1 Capital" laid down in the Rules made by the Regulator.
Confidential Information	means information which, regardless of whether or not the information was received by virtue of a requirement to provide it imposed by or under these Regulations—
(a)	relates to the business or other affairs of any person; and
(b)	was received by the recipient for the purposes of, or in the discharge of, any functions of the Regulator under any Rules made by or under these Regulations;
unless—
(c)	the information has been made available to the public by virtue of being disclosed in any circumstances in which, or for any purposes for which, disclosure is not precluded by this section; or
(d)	it is in the form of a summary or collection of information so framed that it is not possible to ascertain from it information relating to any particular person.
Conversion Rate	means the ratio that determines the number of Shares into which a liability of a specific class will be converted, by reference either to a single instrument of the class or to a specified unit of value of a debt claim.
Core Business Lines	means business lines and associated services which represent material sources of revenue, profit or franchise value for an Institution or an Institution's Group.
Covered Bond	means a bond issued by an Institution where the proceeds from the issue of those bonds shall be invested in assets which, during the whole period of validity of the bonds, are capable of covering claims attaching to the bonds and which, in the event of failure of the Institution, would be used on a priority basis for the reimbursement of the principal and payment of the accrued interest.
Crisis Management Measure	means—
(a)	the exercise of a Resolution Action in relation to an Institution by the Regulator;
(b)	the recognition of a Foreign Resolution Action by the Regulator; or
(c)	the exercise of a Resolution Power in support of a Foreign Resolution Action by the Regulator.
Crisis Prevention Measure	means—
(a)	the imposition by the Regulator of a requirement to take relevant measures with respect to an Institution's recovery plan;
(b)	the imposition by the Regulator of a requirement to take measures to remove impediments to the recoverability of an Institution;
(c)	the imposition of an early intervention measure described in section ‎18‎(4);
(d)	the appointment of a temporary administrator under section ‎19‎(1); or
(e)	the exercise of the Write Down or Conversion Power.
Critical Clearing Services	means central counterparty clearing services the withdrawal of which may, in the Regulator's opinion, threaten the stability of the financial system of the ADGM.
Critical Functions	means activities, services or operations the discontinuance of which is likely to lead to the disruption of services that are essential to the real economy in the ADGM or relevant to Institutions operating in the ADGM the disruption of financial stability due to the size, market share, external or internal interconnectedness, complexity, or cross-border activities of an Institution or Institution's Group, with particular regard to the substitutability of those activities, services or operations.
Debt Instruments	means bonds and other forms of transferable debt, instruments creating or acknowledging debt and instruments giving rights to acquire debt instruments.
Default Event Provision	means a provision of a contract or other agreement—
(a)	that has the effect that if a specified event or situation arises—
(i)	the agreement is terminated, modified, replaced or suspended;
(ii)	rights or duties under the agreement are terminated, modified, replaced or suspended;
(iii)	a right accrues to terminate, modify or replace the agreement;
(iv)	a right accrues to terminate, modify or replace rights or duties under the agreement;
(v)	a set-off or netting right accrues under the contract;
(vi)	a sum becomes payable or ceases to be payable;
(vii)	a right accrues to obtain possession, exercise control or enforce any security over any property;
(viii)	delivery of anything becomes due or ceases to be due;
(ix)	a right to claim a payment or delivery accrues, changes or lapses;
(x)	any other right accrues, changes or lapses; or
(xi)	an interest is created, changes or lapses; or
(b)	that has the effect that a provision of the contract or agreement—
(i)	takes effect only if a specified event occurs or does not occur;
(ii)	takes effect only if a specified situation arises or does not arise;
(iii)	has effect only for so long as a specified event does not occur;
(iv)	has effect only while a specified situation lasts;
(v)	applies differently if a specified event occurs;
(vi)	applies differently if a specified situation occurs; or
(vii)	applies differently while a specified situation lasts.
Definitive Valuation	means a valuation carried out under section ‎37.

Deposit	has the meaning given to that term in paragraph 85 of Schedule 1 in the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 and "Depositor" shall be interpreted accordingly.
Derivative Contract	has the meaning given to that term in section 258 of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015.
Difference of Treatment Valuation	means a valuation carried out under section ‎68.

Director	has the meaning given to that term under section 146 of the Companies Regulations 2015.
Document	means any record of information recorded physically, electronically or in any other form and, in relation to information recorded otherwise than in legible form, references to its production include references to producing a copy of the information in legible form, or in a form from which it can readily be produced in visible and legible form.
Early Intervention Action	means—
(a)	the taking of an early intervention measure (as defined in section ‎18);
(b)	the appointment of temporary administrator under section ‎19; or
(c)	the variation of the terms of engagement of a temporary administrator under section ‎19‎(13).

Eligible Depositor	means a person (other than a market counterparty or a bank) who, at the relevant time, is a creditor of a bank which is an Abu Dhabi Global Market firm by virtue of being owed an amount of money held by the bank as a Deposit and "Eligible Deposit" shall be interpreted accordingly.
Eligible Liabilities	means liabilities and capital instruments that do not qualify as Common Equity Tier 1 Capital instruments, Additional Tier 1 Capital instruments or Tier 2 Capital instruments of an Institution that are not excluded from the exercise of the Write Down or Conversion Power under section ‎49‎(7).

Financial Contracts	includes the following contracts and agreements—
(a)	securities contracts, including—
(i)	contracts for the purchase, sale or loan of a security, a group or index of securities;
(ii)	options on a security or group or index of securities; and
(iii)	repurchase or reverse repurchase transactions on any such security, group or index;
(b)	commodities contracts, including—
(i)	contracts for the purchase, sale or loan of a commodity or group or index of commodities for future delivery;
(ii)	options on a commodity or group or index of commodities; and
(iii)	repurchase or reverse repurchase transactions on any such commodity, group or index;
(c)	futures and forwards contracts, including contracts (other than a commodities contract) for the purchase, sale or transfer of—
(i)	a commodity or property of any other description;
(ii)	a service; or
(iii)	a right or interest;
for a specified price at a future date;
(d)	swap agreements, including—
(i)	swaps and options relating to interest rates, spot or other foreign exchange agreements, currency, an equity index or equity, a debt index or debt, a commodity index or commodity, weather, emissions or inflation;
(ii)	total return, credit spread or credit swaps; and
(iii)	any agreements or transactions that are similar to an agreement referred to in subsections ‎(i) or ‎(ii) which is the subject of recurrent dealing in the swaps or derivatives markets;
(e)	inter-bank borrowing agreements where the term of the borrowing is three months or less; and
(f)	master agreements for any of the contracts or agreements referred to in subsections ‎(a) to ‎(e).

Intragroup Financial Support	includes—

Recognised Investment Exchange	has the meaning given to that term in section 258 of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015.

NamedEntities.agreement: negotiated understanding between two or more parties, reflecting the offer and acceptance of commitments on the part of either party
NamedEntities.opinion: judgement, appraisal, or view about something
NamedEntities.bond: tradable debt instrument representing a loan in which the issuer owes the holder(s) a debt
NamedEntities.account: container for records associated with a business arrangement for regular transactions and services
NamedEntities.investment account: account that provides a record of deposits of funds and/or securities held at a financial institution
NamedEntities.commodity index: investment vehicle that tracks a basket of commodities to measure their price and investment return performance
NamedEntities.contract: voluntary, deliberate agreement between competent parties to which the parties agree to be legally bound, and for which the parties provide valuable consideration
NamedEntities.counterparty: party to a contract with whom one negotiates on a given agreement
NamedEntities.control: situation in which some party has the power to direct or strongly influence the direction of the management and policies related to something
NamedEntities.subsidiary: legal entity that is entirely or majority owned and controlled by another legal entity
NamedEntities.default event: credit event representing a failure to meet a contractual obligation, such as failure to repay a debt including interest or principal on a loan or security
NamedEntities.amount of money: amount of readily available cash in banknotes and coins
NamedEntities.currency: medium of exchange value, defined by reference to the geographical location of the monetary authorities responsible for it
NamedEntities.price: amount of money, goods, or services requested, expected, required, or given in exchange for something else
NamedEntities.collateral: something pledged as security to ensure fulfillment of an obligation to another party, to lend money, extend credit, or provision securities
NamedEntities.creditor: a party to whom an obligation, such as an amount of money, or good, or performance of some service exists
NamedEntities.debt: obligation to pay something, such as an amount of money, good, service, or instrument
NamedEntities.interest: the cost of using credit, or another's money, expressed as a rate per period of time, payable by a debtor to a creditor in consideration of the credit extended to the debtor
NamedEntities.principal: with respect to a debt: the value of an obligation, such as a bond or loan, raised and that must be repaid at maturity; for investments: the original amount of money invested, separate from any associated interest, dividends or capital gains
NamedEntities.share: financial instrument that signifies a unit of equity ownership in a corporation, or a unit of ownership in a mutual fund, or interest in a general or limited partnership, or a unit of ownership in a structured product, such as a real estate investment trust
NamedEntities.clearing: The process by which securities trades are cleared.
NamedEntities.future: derivative instrument that obligates the buyer to receive and the seller to deliver the assets specified at an agreed price, at some later point in time
NamedEntities.security: financial instrument that can be bought or sold
NamedEntities.bank: depository institution, usually a corporation, that accepts deposits, makes loans, pays checks, and performs related services, for individual members of the public, businesses or other organizations
NamedEntities.central securities depository: functional entity that provides a central point for depositing financial instruments ('securities'), for example, bonds and shares
NamedEntities.clearing house: financial service provider that is exchange affiliated and provides clearing services, including the validation, delivery, and settlement of financial transactions, for financial intermediaries
NamedEntities.financial institution: financial service provider identified as either a government agency or privately owned entity that collects funds from the public and from other institutions, and invests those funds in financial assets, such as loans, securities, bank deposits, and income-generating property
NamedEntities.branch: part of a larger organization that might not be co-located with it
NamedEntities.group: collection of agents (people, organizations, software agents, etc.) that are considered as a unit
NamedEntities.index: indirect shortcut derived from and pointing into, a greater volume of values, data, information or knowledge
NamedEntities.jurisdiction: power of a court to adjudicate cases, issue orders, and interpret and apply the law with respect to some specific geographic area
NamedEntities.claim: demand or assertion made by one party on another, based on facts that, taken together, give rise to a legally enforceable right or judicial action
NamedEntities.right: entitlement (not) to perform certain actions, or (not) to be in certain states; or entitlement that others (not) perform certain actions or (not) be in certain states
NamedEntities.law: rule recognized by some community as regulating the behavior of its members and that it may enforce through the imposition of penalties
NamedEntities.legal entity: legal person that is a partnership, corporation, or other organization having the capacity to negotiate contracts, assume financial obligations, and pay off debts, organized under the laws of some jurisdiction
NamedEntities.legal person: autonomous agent that is recognized as having rights and obligations under the law, including but not limited to the right to sue and be sued, enter into contracts, own property, and incur financial and other obligations
NamedEntities.exchange: any organization, association, or group of persons, whether incorporated or unincorporated, which constitutes, maintains, or provides a facility for bringing together purchasers and sellers of financial instruments, commodities, or other products, services, or goods, and includes the market place and facilities maintained by such exchange

DefinedTerms.Accepting Deposits:
In relation to:
(a)	FUNDS, means:
(i)	money received by way of Deposit is lent to others; or
(ii)	any other activity of the Person accepting the Deposit is financed, wholly or to a material extent, out of the capital of or returns on any money received by way of Deposit; and
(b)	GEN and FEES, has the meaning given in paragraph 38 of Schedule 1 of FSMR.
DefinedTerms.Acting as a Central Securities Depositor: Has the meaning given in section 258 of FSMR.
DefinedTerms.ADGM: Means the Abu Dhabi Global Market.
DefinedTerms.ADGM Founding Law: Means Abu Dhabi Law No. 4 of 2013 concerning the ADGM issued by His Highness the Ruler of the Emirate of Abu Dhabi.
DefinedTerms.Assets: Means, unless specified otherwise, collateral held to cover positions and includes the right to the transfer of assets equivalent to that collateral or the proceeds of the realisation of any collateral, but does not include Default Fund Contributions.
DefinedTerms.Authorised Person: Means a Person, other than a Recognised Body, who is authorised under the FSMR.
DefinedTerms.Branch:
Means a place of business within the ADGM which:
(a)	has no separate legal personality;
(b)	forms a legally dependant part of an Authorised Person whose principal place of business and head office is in a jurisdiction other than the ADGM; and
(c)	through which the Authorised Person carries on Regulated Activities in or from the ADGM.
DefinedTerms.Capital: Means Tier 1 Capital, as defined in PRU.
DefinedTerms.Capital Resources: Means the total capital resources of an Authorised Person calculated in accordance with PRU 3.15.
DefinedTerms.Clearing: Means, in relation to a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House, the process of establishing positions, including the calculation of net obligations and ensuring that Securities, cash, or both, are available to secure the exposures arising from those positions.
DefinedTerms.Clearing Services:
Means:
(a)	the services provided by a Recognised Body or Remote Body in connection with contracts between each of the parties or the Recognised Body or Remote Body (in place of, or as an alternative to, a contract directly between the parties);
(b)	the services provided by a Recognised Body or Remote Body to another Recognised Body or Remote Body in connection with contracts between them; or
(c)	the services provided by a Recognised Investment Exchange to a Recognised Clearing House or to another Recognised Investment Exchange in connection with contracts between them,
for the purpose of enabling the rights and liabilities of that Member, Recognised Investment Exchange, Remote Body or other Recognised Clearing House under a transaction to be settled.
DefinedTerms.Client: Means a Retail Client or Professional Client as defined in COBS 2.
DefinedTerms.Client Assets: Means Client Money and Client Investments.
DefinedTerms.Client Investments: Means all Investments held or controlled on behalf of Client in the course of, or in connection with, the carrying on of the Investment Business.
DefinedTerms.Client Money: Means money of any currency which an Authorised Person holds on behalf of a Client (including any receivables of the Authorised Person in respect of bank accounts or clearing or brokerage accounts) or which an Authorised Person treats as Client Money, subject to the exclusions in COBS 14.3.1.
DefinedTerms.Collateral: Means a Client Investment which has been paid for in full by a Client and which is held or controlled by the Authorised Person under the terms of a deposit, pledge, charge or other security arrangement.
DefinedTerms.Dealing in Investments as Principal: Has the meaning given in paragraph 4 of Schedule 1 of FSMR.
DefinedTerms.Deposit:
In relation to:
(a)	FEES, has the meaning given in paragraph 85 of Schedule 1 of FSMR; and
(b)	FUNDS and COBS,  means a sum of money paid on terms:
(i)	under which it will be repaid, with or without interest or a premium, and either on demand or at a time or in circumstances agreed by or on behalf of the Person making the payment and the Person receiving it; and
(ii)	which is not referable to the provision of property (other than currency) or services or the giving of security.
(iii)	In (i) money is paid on terms which may be made by reference to the provision of property or services or the giving of security if:
(A)	it is paid by way of advance or part payment under a contract for the sale, hire or other provision of property or services, and is repayable only in the event that the property or services are not in fact sold, hired or otherwise provided;
(B)	it is paid by way of security for the performance of a contract or by way of security in respect of loss which may result from the non performance of a contract; or
(C)	without prejudice to (ii), it is paid by way of security for the delivery up of property, whether in a particular state of repair or otherwise.

A Business Reorganisation Plan shall contain at least the following—
(a)	a detailed diagnosis of the factors and problems that caused the Institution to fail or to be likely to fail and the circumstances that led to its difficulties;
(b)	a description of the measures aiming to restore the long-term viability of the Institution or parts of its business that are to be adopted, on the basis of realistic assumptions as to the economic and financial market conditions under which the Institution will operate; and
(c)	a timescale for the implementation of those measures.
Obligations:
Obligation:1 "Diagnosis of Failure Factors:**
   - Conduct a thorough analysis to identify the reasons behind the institution's failure or potential failure.
   - Document the problems and factors that contributed to the institution's financial difficulties, including management decisions, market conditions, operational issues, and external factors.
   - Provide a detailed report on the problems encountered, including operational, strategic, financial, or market-related issues."

Obligation:2 "Restoration Measures:**
   - Develop a comprehensive set of measures aimed at restoring the long-term viability of the institution or the viable parts of its business.
   - Include financial restructuring, operational changes, management reshuffling, strategic pivots, cost-cutting, asset divestitures, etc., based on realistic assumptions about future economic and financial market conditions.
   - Ensure that the proposed measures are feasible and have a reasonable chance of success."

Obligation:3 "Implementation Timescale:**
   - Create a clear and achievable timeline for implementing the restoration measures, with specific milestones and deadlines.
   - Ensure the timescale is realistic, considering the complexity of the measures and the operational capacity of the institution."

Obligation:4 "Documentation and Reporting:**
   - Document all aspects of the Business Reorganisation Plan in a clear, structured, and comprehensive manner.
   - Prepare to present and explain the plan to regulatory authorities, stakeholders, and possibly creditors or investors.
   - Ensure that the plan satisfies the regulatory requirements as stipulated by the ADGM."

Obligation:5 "Compliance and Monitoring:**
   - Monitor the progress of the plan's implementation closely and ensure compliance with its measures and timelines.
   - Adjust the plan as necessary in response to changing conditions and report significant changes or deviations to regulatory authorities."

Obligation:6 "Communication:**
   - Communicate effectively with all stakeholders, including regulatory authorities, employees, creditors, investors, shareholders, and customers.
   - Keep stakeholders informed about the progress of the reorganisation and any material changes to the plan."

Obligation:7 "Regulatory Engagement:**
   - Engage with the ADGM Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA) and other relevant regulatory bodies throughout the reorganisation process.
   - Meet all regulatory requirements, including necessary approvals or notifications related to the reorganisation plan.
   - Seek guidance or clarification from the FSRA if there are uncertainties about regulatory expectations or requirements.

Passage:
In complying with the requirements under section 68, the Regulator shall exercise the Write Down or Conversion Power under section ‎64 in accordance with the priority of claims under Insolvency Proceedings, in a way that produces the following results—
(a)	Common Equity Tier 1 Capital items are reduced first in proportion to the losses and to the extent of their capacity and the Regulator takes one or both of the actions specified in section ‎51‎(1) in respect of the holders of Common Equity Tier 1 Capital instruments;
(b)	the principal amount of Additional Tier 1 Capital instruments is written down or converted into Common Equity Tier 1 Capital instruments or both, to the extent required to achieve the Resolution Objectives or to the extent of the capacity of the Non-CET1 Capital Instruments, whichever is lower; and
(c)	the principal amount of Tier 2 Capital instruments is written down or converted into Common Equity Tier 1 Capital instruments or both, to the extent required to achieve the Resolution Objectives or to the extent of the capacity of the Non-CET1 Capital Instruments, whichever is lower.
Obligations:
Obligation:1 "Prepare CET1 Capital Instruments for Loss Absorption**:
   - Be ready for Common Equity Tier 1 Capital instruments to be reduced first in response to losses."

Obligation:2 "Ensure Compliance with Write-Down and Conversion Terms**:
   - Verify that the terms and conditions of Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 Capital instruments include provisions for write-down or conversion."

Obligation:3 "Manage Expectations of Instrument Holders**:
   - Inform and manage the expectations of capital instrument holders regarding the potential for their instruments to be affected in a resolution scenario."

Obligation:4 "Participate in Resolution Planning**:
   - Prepare and maintain resolution plans that detail how the Write Down or Conversion Power would be implemented for your institution."

Obligation:5 "Maintain Regulatory Reporting and Disclosure**:
   - Comply with reporting and disclosure requirements related to the capital instruments, including reporting on their levels and capacity to absorb losses."

Obligation:6 "Engage with the Regulator**:
   - Proactively engage with the Regulator to understand the specific implications of these obligations for your institution and ensure compliance."

Obligation:7 "Consult with Legal and Compliance Professionals**:
   - Seek advice from legal and compliance professionals within your organization or external advisors to ensure full compliance with the regulatory requirements."

Obligation:8 "Respect the Insolvency Hierarchy**:
   - Ensure that any actions taken in exercising the Write Down or Conversion Power respect the priority of claims as would be applied in insolvency proceedings, following the hierarchy of CET1, AT1, and Tier 2 Capital instruments.

By consolidating these action items, you can create a comprehensive checklist to ensure that your financial institution is prepared for the exercise of Write Down or Conversion Power by the Regulator in the ADGM."

Where the principal amount of a Non-CET1 Capital Instrument is written down—
(a)	the reduction of that principal amount shall be permanent, subject to any write up in accordance with section ‎50‎(3);
(b)	no liability to the holder of the Non-CET1 Capital Instrument, or right on the part of such holder, shall remain under or in connection with that amount of the instrument which has been written down, except in respect of any liability already accrued, and any liability calculated following a Difference in Treatment calculation in accordance with section 69 (but this shall not prevent the provision of Common Equity Tier 1 Capital instruments to a holder of Non-CET1 Capital Instruments in accordance with subsection ‎(3); and
(c)	no compensation is paid to any holder of the Non-CET1 Capital Instruments other than in accordance with subsection ‎(3).
Obligations: Obligation:1 "Ensure Permanent Write-Down**: Confirm that any write-down of the principal amount of Non-CET1 Capital Instruments is permanent, with the exception of scenarios where a write-up is explicitly permitted by the regulations."

Obligation:2 "Terminate Liabilities or Rights**: After a write-down, ensure that no further liabilities exist for the holder of the Non-CET1 Capital Instrument regarding the written-down amount, except for:
   - Liabilities that have already accrued.
   - Liabilities calculated in accordance with a Difference in Treatment calculation as specified in the regulations."

Obligation:3 "Prohibit Unallowed Compensation**: Do not provide compensation to holders of Non-CET1 Capital Instruments for the written-down amount, unless it is within the specific conditions allowed by the regulations."

Obligation:4 "Comply with CET1 Instruments Provision**: If providing Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) Capital Instruments to holders of Non-CET1 Capital Instruments, ensure that this is done in compliance with the conditions outlined in the regulations."

Obligation:5 "Review Regulatory Framework**: Thoroughly review the specific terms and conditions of the Non-CET1 Capital Instruments, as well as the full regulatory framework, including any relevant sections that detail the conditions for write-ups and compensations."
Obligation:6 "Establish Compliance Procedures**: Develop and implement internal procedures that adhere to the write-down process, termination of liabilities, and compensation rules."
Obligation:7 "Maintain Accurate Records**: Keep detailed records of all transactions and actions related to the write-down of Non-CET1 Capital Instruments."
Obligation:8 "Communicate with Instrument Holders**: Ensure clear communication with holders of Non-CET1 Capital Instruments regarding their rights and any changes to their instruments."
Obligation:9 "Seek Legal Advice**: Consider consulting the full text of the ADGM regulations or obtaining legal advice to ensure full compliance with all regulatory requirements."

Treatment of Shareholders in the case of partial transfers and application of the bail in tool
Where one or more of the Resolution Tools have been applied, the Regulator shall be guided by the following principles—
(a)	except where subsection ‎(b) applies, where the Regulator transfers only part of the rights, assets and liabilities of the Institution in Resolution, the Shareholders and creditors whose claims have not been transferred should, to the extent reasonably practicable, receive in satisfaction of their claims at least as much as they would have received if the Institution in Resolution had been Wound Up under Insolvency Proceedings at the time (when the Regulator delivered notice in accordance with section 24(3)); and
(b)	where the Regulator applies the Bail-in Tool, the Shareholders and creditors whose claims have been written down or converted to Shares should, to the extent reasonably practicable, not incur greater losses than they would have incurred if the Institution in Resolution had been Wound Up under Insolvency Proceedings immediately at the time (when the Regulator delivered notice in accordance with section 24(3)).
Obligations:
Obligation:1 "Assess Valuation for Fair Treatment**:
   - Conduct a valuation of the institution's assets, rights, and liabilities to determine what would have been realized if the institution had been wound up under insolvency proceedings."

Obligation:2 "Ensure Equitable Treatment**:
   - Guarantee that shareholders and creditors receive at least as much as they would have in a winding-up scenario when partial transfers are involved.
   - Ensure that losses incurred by shareholders and creditors under the bail-in tool do not exceed what they would have faced in insolvency proceedings."

Obligation:3 "Maintain Documentation and Communication**:
   - Keep detailed records of the resolution process, including valuations and comparisons.
   - Communicate effectively with affected parties about their rights and the rationale for the resolution strategy."

Obligation:4 "Comply with Regulatory Requirements**:
   - Adhere to all relevant ADGM regulations and guidelines.
   - Cooperate with the Regulator during the resolution process.
   - Report to the ADGM Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA) as required, providing evidence of compliance with the principles."

Obligation:5 "Seek Professional Advice**:
   - Consult with legal and compliance professionals for a detailed analysis and guidance tailored to your specific situation within the resolution process."

Obligation:6 "Engage with the Resolution Process** (if a shareholder, creditor, or part of the management):
   - Participate actively in the resolution process and provide necessary information as required by the regulator."

Obligation:3 "Meet Reporting and Disclosure Requirements**: Report necessary information to authorities and disclose certain information publicly as required."
Obligation:4 "Maintain MREL**: Ensure sufficient own funds and eligible liabilities to absorb losses and recapitalize if needed."
Obligation:5 "Comply with Termination Rights Stays**: Adhere to any temporary stays on contractual termination rights during resolution."
Obligation:6 "Cooperate with Authorities**: Provide requested information and support to regulatory and resolution authorities."
Obligation:7 "Ensure Compatible Governance Arrangements**: Align governance with recovery and resolution planning."
Obligation:8 "Fulfill Notification Requirements**: Inform the regulatory authority of events impacting financial condition or operational continuity."
Obligation:9 "Prepare for Moratorium Powers**: Understand and plan for potential moratoriums imposed by the resolution authority."
Obligation:10 "Anticipate Bail-in Tool**: Be ready for liabilities to be written down or converted to equity in resolution."
Obligation:11 "Implement Restructuring Measures**: Carry out restructuring as required by the resolution authority to restore viability."
Obligation:12 "Facilitate Resolvability Assessments**: Participate in assessments and address any obstacles to resolution."
Obligation:13 "Enter Intra-Group Financial Support Agreements**: Establish agreements for financial support within the group."
Obligation:14 "Respond to Early Intervention**: Take actions as directed by the FSRA in response to breaches or potential breaches of requirements."
Obligation:15 "Understand Resolution Tools and Powers**: Be aware of the FSRA's tools and powers for resolving failed institutions."

Obligation:16 "Participate in Cross-Border Group Resolution**: Engage in planning and information sharing for group resolution involving foreign authorities.

For a precise understanding of obligations, review the full text of the Bank Recovery and Resolution Regulations 2018, consider the specific nature of the business, and seek legal advice or guidance from the ADGM Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA) or a compliance professional."

NamedEntities.bank: depository institution, usually a corporation, that accepts deposits, makes loans, pays checks, and performs related services, for individual members of the public, businesses or other organizations

DefinedTerms.Bank: Means an Authorised Person which holds a Financial Services Permission authorising it to carry on the Regulated Activity of Accepting Deposits.

Passage: These Regulations shall apply in the ADGM.

DefinedTerms.ADGM: Means the Abu Dhabi Global Market.

Passage: These Regulations shall come into force on the date of their publication.
Obligations: Obligation:1 "Provide the title or reference number of the regulations in question."
Obligation:2 "Confirm the regulatory body that issued these regulations (e.g., ADGM)."
Obligation:3 "Describe the sector or type of financial activities that the regulations govern."
Obligation:4 "Specify the nature of your business or financial activities within the ADGM."
Obligation:5 "Confirm whether you are a licensed entity and the type of license you hold."
Obligation:6 "Apply for and maintain the appropriate licenses or authorizations to operate in the ADGM."
Obligation:7 "Implement internal policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the regulations."
Obligation:8 "Conduct customer due diligence and maintain records as required by AML/CFT regulations."
Obligation:9 "Submit regular financial reports and disclosures to the ADGM Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA)."
Obligation:10 "Ensure the protection of client assets and data privacy."
Obligation:11 "Adhere to capital and liquidity requirements to manage financial risks."
Obligation:1 "Prepare Recovery Plan Summary**: Create a summary of the Recovery Plan's key elements and overall recovery capacity."
Obligation:2 "Document Material Changes**: Record any significant changes to the institution since the last Recovery Plan update."
Obligation:3 "Develop Communication Plan**: Formulate a strategy to manage negative market reactions during financial distress."
Obligation:4 "Outline Recovery Actions**: Specify a range of actions to maintain or restore viability, including capital, liquidity, and loss allocation measures."
Obligation:5 "Establish Implementation Procedures**: Set conditions and procedures for timely implementation of recovery actions."
Obligation:6 "Identify Early Intervention Measures**: Determine measures for early intervention as specified in section ‎18."
Obligation:7 "Estimate Execution Timeframes**: Calculate the time required to execute each aspect of the Recovery Plan."
Obligation:8 "Describe Execution Impediments**: Identify any obstacles to the effective and prompt execution of the Recovery Plan."
Obligation:9 "Identify Critical Functions**: Pinpoint the institution's essential functions that must be preserved during a crisis."
Obligation:10 "Valuate Core Business Lines**: Describe the process for valuing and assessing the marketability of core business lines and assets."
Obligation:11 "Integrate into Corporate Governance**: Explain how recovery planning is incorporated into the corporate governance structure."
Obligation:12 "Detail Recognised Clearing House Specifics**: If relevant, describe the integration of recovery planning into operating rules for non-defaulting clearing members."
Obligation:13 "Establish Capital Conservation Measures**: Set up measures to conserve or restore Capital Resources."
Obligation:14 "Ensure Contingency Funding**: Secure access to contingency funding and assess collateral and liquidity transfer options."
Obligation:15 "Implement Risk Reduction Measures**: Put in place measures to reduce risk and leverage."
Obligation:16 "Restructure Contracts and Liabilities**: Create arrangements to restructure contracts, rights, assets, and liabilities."
Obligation:17 "Restructure Business Lines**: Implement measures to restructure business lines."
Obligation:18 "Maintain Access to Financial Markets Infrastructures**: Ensure continuous access to financial markets infrastructures."
Obligation:19 "Ensure Operational Continuity**: Keep operational processes, infrastructure, and IT services functioning continuously."
Obligation:20 "Prepare for Asset/Business Line Sale**: Get ready for the potential sale of assets or business lines to restore financial health."
Obligation:21 "Outline Restoration Strategies**: Present other management actions or strategies to restore financial soundness and their expected financial impact."
Obligation:22 "Take Recapitalisation Preparatory Measures**: Implement measures necessary for the timely recapitalisation as part of the Recovery Plan."

Obligation:23 "Develop Indicators Framework**: Construct a framework of indicators to signal when to initiate Recovery Plan actions.

These action items should be addressed in the institution's Recovery Plan to ensure readiness for financial distress and compliance with ADGM regulations. The Recovery Plan should be regularly reviewed and updated to reflect changes in the institution's structure, risk profile, or external environment. Compliance with these action items is essential for maintaining financial stability and regulatory compliance within the ADGM framework."

Obligations: Obligation:1 "Provide a detailed description of the institution's organizational structure."
Obligation:2 "Identify direct holders and their respective voting and non-voting rights percentages."
Obligation:3 "Supply information on the location, jurisdiction of incorporation, licensing, and key management for each entity within the organizational structure."
Obligation:4 "Map critical operations and core business lines, including material asset holdings and liabilities."
Obligation:5 "Detail the institution's liabilities, categorized by types and amounts or services and respective amounts, depending on the institution's nature."
Obligation:6 "Provide details of liabilities that are considered eligible liabilities."
Obligation:7 "Identify capital instruments and debt instruments issued by the institution and its legal entities."
Obligation:8 "Identify collateral pledging and receiving processes, including the holder and location of the collateral."
Obligation:9 "Describe off-balance sheet exposures and map them to critical operations and core business lines."
Obligation:10 "Detail material hedges and map them to legal entities."
Obligation:11 "Identify major or critical counterparties or clearing members and analyze the impact of their failure."
Obligation:12 "List systems used for a significant number of trades and map them to the institution's structure and critical operations."
Obligation:13 "Detail membership in payment, securities settlement systems, clearinghouses, exchanges, etc., and map them to the institution's operations and business lines."
Obligation:14 "Provide an inventory and description of key management information systems, including those for risk management, accounting, and reporting."
Obligation:15 "Identify system owners, service level agreements, software, and systems or licenses, and map them."
Obligation:16 "Map and identify interconnections and interdependencies among legal entities."
Obligation:17 "Identify the applicable regulator and resolution authority for each entity."
Obligation:18 "Name the management member responsible for providing information for the resolution plan."
Obligation:19 "Describe arrangements to ensure necessary information is provided to the Regulator in the event of resolution."
Obligation:20 "List agreements with third parties that may be terminated by the Regulator's decision to apply a resolution tool and the potential impact of such terminations."
Obligation:21 "Describe potential liquidity sources to support resolution."

Obligation:22 "Provide information on asset encumbrance, liquid assets, off-balance sheet activities, hedging strategies, and booking practices.

These action items are essential for maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements for resolution planning and must be kept accurate, comprehensive, and up-to-date. Failure to comply may result in regulatory action."

Obligations: Obligation:1 "Prepare a Summary of the Resolution Plan**: Create a concise summary that captures the key elements of your Resolution Plan."
Obligation:2 "Report Material Changes**: Summarize any significant changes to your institution since the last Resolution information was submitted."

Obligation:3 "Demonstrate Separability**: Show how Critical Functions and Core Business Lines can be legally and economically separated from other operations to ensure their continuity in the event of the institution's failure."
Obligation:4 "Estimate Timeframes**: Provide an estimated timeline for implementing each significant component of the Resolution Plan."
Obligation:5 "Assessment of Resolvability**: Include a detailed description of the resolvability assessment, if applicable, as per the relevant chapter and part of the regulations."
Obligation:6 "Address Impediments to Resolvability**: Describe measures taken to address or remove any identified barriers to resolvability."
Obligation:7 "Value and Marketability Processes**: Explain the processes for determining the value and marketability of the institution's Critical Functions, Core Business Lines, and assets."
Obligation:8 "Resolution Strategies**: Provide a detailed description of various resolution strategies for different scenarios, including the relevant timescales."
Obligation:9 "Critical Interdependencies**: Describe any critical interdependencies within the institution that could affect the resolution process."
Obligation:10 "Access to Financial Infrastructure**: Outline options for maintaining access to payment and securities settlement systems and assess the portability of client positions."

Obligation:11 "Impact on Employees**: Analyze the impact of the Resolution Plan on employees, including cost assessments and procedures for consulting staff, while respecting national dialogue systems with social partners."
Obligation:12 "Communication Plan**: Develop a communication plan for interacting with the media and the public during the resolution process."

Obligation:13 "Capital Resources and Eligible Liabilities**: Document the minimum requirement for capital resources and eligible liabilities as required by the regulator, including a deadline to reach the prescribed level."
Obligation:14 "Bail-in Instruments**: If applicable, state the minimum requirement for capital resources and contractual bail-in instruments, along with a deadline to achieve this requirement."
Obligation:15 "Essential Operations and Systems**: Describe the essential operations and systems necessary for maintaining continuous functioning of the institution's operational processes."

Obligation:16 "Regulator's Opinion**: Include any opinion expressed by the regulator in relation to the Resolution Plan, if applicable.

Regularly review and update the Resolution Plan to ensure it remains comprehensive, up-to-date, and in compliance with ADGM regulations, reflecting any changes in the institution's structure, business, or regulatory environment. Compliance with these obligations is mandatory for the orderly resolution of the institution, minimizing systemic risk, and protecting taxpayers from loss."

Obligations:
Obligation:1 "Map Core Business Lines and Critical Operations:**
   - Map out core business lines and critical operations to specific legal entities within the institution."

Obligation:2 "Align Legal and Corporate Structures:**
   - Align legal and corporate structures with core business lines and critical operations to facilitate resolution."

Obligation:3 "Support and Maintenance Arrangements:**
   - Ensure arrangements are in place for essential staff, infrastructure, funding, liquidity, and capital to support core business lines and critical operations."

Obligation:4 "Service Agreements:**
   - Ensure all service agreements are fully enforceable in the event of resolution.
   - Maintain an adequate governance structure to manage compliance with service level agreements.
   - Establish a process for transitioning services to third parties if necessary."

Obligation:5 "Contingency Planning:**
   - Implement contingency plans for continuity in access to payment and securities settlement systems, clearinghouses, and exchanges."

Obligation:6 "Management Information Systems (MIS):**
   - Ensure MIS is adequate for rapid and accurate information gathering and decision-making during resolution.
   - Test MIS under stress scenarios as defined by the regulator.
   - Ensure continuity of MIS post-separation of critical operations and core business lines."

Obligation:7 "Depositor Information:**
   - Establish processes to provide the regulator with necessary information to identify depositors."

Obligation:8 "Intragroup Financial Support and Transactions:**
   - Ensure intragroup financial support and back-to-back transactions are at market conditions with robust risk management systems.
   - Assess and mitigate the risk of contagion within the group due to these arrangements."

Obligation:9 "Legal Structure and Resolution Tools:**
   - Evaluate whether the legal structure of the institution or group inhibits the application of resolution tools."

Obligation:10 "Resolution Planning:**
    - Assess the feasibility of applying resolution tools in a way that meets resolution objectives.
    - Consider the impact of the institution's resolution on its group entities and the wider financial system.
    - Ensure cooperation with resolution authorities in other jurisdictions.
    - Understand the arrangements for facilitating resolution in cases of groups with cross-jurisdictional entities."

Obligation:11 "Impact Assessment:**
    - Evaluate the potential impact of the institution's resolution on the financial system, market confidence, and the economy in the ADGM.
    - Contain potential contagion to other institutions or financial markets through the application of resolution tools."

Obligation:12 "Financial Market Infrastructures:**
    - Assess the effect of the institution's resolution on the operation of payment and securities settlement systems and other financial market infrastructures."

Obligation:13 "Regular Review and Updating:**
    - Regularly review and update resolution plans and preparedness measures to ensure they remain effective and compliant with ADGM's regulatory requirements.

These action items should be actively managed to ensure that the institution is prepared for a resolution scenario, minimizing the impact on financial stability and protecting public funds while ensuring the continuity of critical functions. Compliance with these obligations will help ensure that the institution can be resolved in an orderly manner without causing undue harm to the financial system or the economy."
